titleStmt.title: Persian MS 969
titleStmt.funder: The John Rylands Research Institute and Library

msDesc.head: This illustrated manuscript features two works excerpted from the Khamsah (Quintet) by Niẓāmī.

msContents.summary: This volume contains the Makhzan al-Asrār (Treasury of Secrets) followed by the Romance of Khusraw and Shīrīn, which both usually comprise the first two works in the Khamsah (Quintet) by Niẓāmī Ganjavī (ca. 1141–1203). Completed by scribe Muḥammad Qāsim Jundabāqānāi (the Arabized form of the Persian name Gulpāyagānī, meaning someone from the town of Golpayagan) in 1024 AH, the volume contains seven illustrations of the commercial Isfahan style

author.persName: Jamāl al-Dīn Abū Muḥammad Ilyās ibn Yūsuf ibn Muʼayyad Niẓām al-Dīn Ganjavī
جمال الدين ابو محمد الياس بن يوسف بن مؤيد نظام الدين گنجوی

msItem.title: Makhzan al-Asrār
مخزن الأسرار
msItem.incipit: برگ ۱پ (folio 38b): ساز آباد خدایا دل ویرانی را * یا مده مهرتان هیچ مسلمانی را
msItem.explicit: برگ ۳۸پ (folio 38b): ساز آباد خدایا دل ویرانی را * یا مده مهرتان هیچ مسلمانی را
msItem.colophon: برگ ۳۸پ (folio 38b): حب الار عالیحضرات حکومت و اقبال پناه شجاعاً رشد پنگا[ه؟] مرقوم شد. فقیر حاجی محمد الکاتب الجردباقانی سنه ۱۰۲۸.
Completed by Ḥājjī Muḥammad [Qāsim] al-Jurdbāqānī on 1028 AH (1619 CE).
msItem.note: The scribe's arabized niṣbah, al-Jurdbāqānī indicates his family originally came from the town of Golpayegan, located near Isfahan. Note that a catalogue entry from the Quaritch firm pasted on the right pastedown erroneously reports the scribe's name as Háji Muhammad Fáni, also repeated in Rafiee-Rad. ‘Arif Naushahi describes a lithographed edition of the Burhān Qātī‘ published in Bombay based upon a manuscript completed by a Muḥammad Bāqir Jurdbāqānī in 1035 AH who may possibly be the same person as the scribe of this volume. For other copies of this same work, including volumes formerly owned by scholar Nathaniel Bland, upon which basis he published his critical edition in 1844, see Rylands Persian MS 9, 35, and 61, in addition to complete copies of the entire Khamsah held in the collection.

author.persName: Jamāl al-Dīn Abū Muḥammad Ilyās ibn Yūsuf ibn Muʼayyad Niẓām al-Dīn Ganjavī
جمال الدين ابو محمد الياس بن يوسف بن مؤيد نظام الدين گنجوی

msItem.title: Khusraw va Shīrīn
خسرو و شیرین
msItem.incipit: برگ ۳۹پ (folio 39b): خداواندا در توفیق بگشای * نظامی را ره تحقیق بنمای.
msItem.explicit: برگ ۱۴۰پ (folio 140): روانش باد جفت نیکنامی * که گوید باد رحمت بر نظامی.
msItem.colophon: برگ ۱۴۰پ (folio 140): در تاریخ سلح شهر ربی الثانی سنه ۲۸[۰]۱ ثمان و عششرین بعد الالف مرقوم بلم شکسته شد رقم اقل اشیا حاجی قاسم جربادقانی.
Completed by Ḥājjī Muḥammad [Qāsim] Jurdbāqānī in Rabī‘ II 1028 AH (Mar.– Apr. 1619 CE).
msItem.note: For an earlier illustrated manuscript of this same work, see Rylands Persian MS 6, in addition to complete copies of the Khamsah held in the collection.

supportDesc.support: Textblock comprised of a straight and cross-grained buff-coloured paper likely handmade in Greater Iran, with ~7 laid lines per mm and no discernible chain lines.
supportDesc.collation: Undetermined. Catchwords on the lower left corners of b sides throughout.
supportDesc.condition: Text in fair condition, with damage, stains, and historical repairs and remargined folios at the beginning and end. Vertical break in the illumination on folio 1. Protruding folios from repairs.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 3 columns with 22 lines per page. Ruled with a misṭarah hand guide.

handDesc.handNote: Written in black nasta‘līq script with red subheaders by Ḥājjī Muḥammad [Qāsim] Jurdbāqānī.

decoDesc.decoNote:
Illustrations:Seven illustrations depict the story of Khusraw and Shīrīn executed in a commercial Isfahan style:
Folio 56b:
Khusraw escapes to Ārman.
Folio 64a:
Khusraw ascends the Madāyin Throne then deaprts for Ārman.
Folio 72b:
Khusraw defeats Bahrām Chūbīn.
Folio 83b:
Farhād’s creates a stream of milk.
Folio 91b:
Shīrīn travels to Bīstūn mountain to visit Farhād.
Folio 64a:
Khusrow sees Shikar Ṣipāhān.
Folio 135a:
The death of Khusraw. Published: Rafiee-Rad, pl. 3.
Illumination: Folios 1b and 39b bear delicately illuminated headpieces

list.item: Folio 1a bears a partially legible dated note adjacent to the oval seal impression of Ḥusn‘alī dated 1293 AH (1876–77 CE).
The final left flyleaf a and b sides (ff. iia–iib) bear various poetic and prose quotes.

binding.p: Unsupported sewing at two stations, edges trimmed, and twined chevron endbands sewn at head and tail worked in yellow and pink silkthreads. Covered in boarded Russia leather over pasteboards without a flap (Type III binding per Déroche), with the spine subsequently rebacked in goatskin leather. Board interiors lined with tan sheepskin leather
binding.decoNote: Boards decorated with recessed gilt leather scalloped central mandorlas and detached pendants bearing arabesque floral palmette scrollwork designs. Board margins tooled with a blind rope design. Interior doublure margins single-ruled in black.
binding.condition: Handle binding with care. In poor condition, with extensive abrasion to the edges, onlays abraded, and headcap torn. Extensive tipping restricts opening to the gutter margins.

sealDesc.summary: A small black over seal impression and a stationer's embossed seal.

seal.decoNote:
1: A small black oval seal impression, intaglio-carved in a single line of nasta‘līq script, double-ruled, bears the name of former owner Ḥusn‘alī dated 1233 AH (1817–18 CE):
812
2: An oval blind embossed stamp, partially legible, appears to bear Cyrillic characters in a ring around the perimeter, likely from a Russian stationer or paper mill. 1621

physDesc.accMat: A card tucked inside the right pastedown bears a pasted entry excerpted from the 1902 catalogue of the London antiquarian firm of Bernard Quaritch (firm) with handwritten observations about the volume.

history.origin: Completed by Ḥājjī Muḥammad Qāsim Jurdbāqānī, probably in Isfahan Rabī‘ II 1028 AH (Mar.– Apr. 1619 CE).

provenance.p: Subsequently owned by one Ḥusn‘alī as per his seal impression on folio 1b.

A catalogue pasted entry upon right pastedown, excerpted from the 1902 catalogue of the London antiquarian firm of Bernard Quaritch (firm) indicates an unidentified individual probably purchased it for £4 4 shillings. Although Siavash Rafiee-Rad implies that Samuel Robinson of Wilmslow formerly owned this manuscript, we find no external nor internal evidence to suggest this.

acquisition.p: Unknown. Probably transferred from the University of Manchester Library to the John Rylands Library after the institutions merged in 1972.

source.p: Bibliographical description derived from Siavash Rafiee-Rad, 'Persian Manuscripts in Samuel Robinson’s Collection in The John Rylands Library' 2017. Record created and manuscript description amended and enhanced by Jake Benson in 2022 with reference to the volume in hand.

availability.p: The manuscript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.

listBibl.bibl: Nathaniel Bland, Niẓāmī Ganjavī, and Nathaniel Bland. Makhzan ul asrár, the treasury of secrets: being the first of the five poems, or khamsah, of Shaikh Nizámi, of Ganjah. London: Society for the Publication of Oriental Texts, 1844.
François de Blois, Persian Literature: A Bio-bibliographical Survey, Vol. V, Pt. 2 (London, Luzac, 1994), pp. 364, 374 .
H. Ethé, Catalogue of Persian Manuscripts in the Library of the India Office, Vol. I (Oxford: Printed for the India Office by H. Hart, 1903) cols. 602–603, no. 989 [BL IO Islamic 1444].
‘Arif Naushahi, Kitāb-shināsī-yi Ās̱ār-i Fārsī-yi Chāp Shudah pp. 830–831, no. 5558
D. Parrello, 'Ḵamsa of Neẓāmī', Encyclopædia Iranica Vol. 15, Fasc. 5 (2011): pp. 451–453.
S. Rafiee-Rad, 'Persian Manuscripts in Samuel Robinson’s Collection in The John Rylands Library', Manuscripta: A Journal for Manuscript Research, Vol. 61, No. 2 (2017): pp. 248–251.
C. Rieu, Catalogue of the Persian manuscripts in the British Museum, Vol. II (London: British Museum, 1881), pp. 565–566 [BL Add. 7729/1].

E. Sachau and H. Ethé, Catalogue of the Persian, Turkish, Hindûstani, and Pushtû manuscripts in the Bodleian Library Vol I. (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1889), col. 494, nos. 600–603 [Bodl. Ouseley 302, Ouseley Add. 107, Marsh 369, sale 29].
Bernard Quaritch (firm), A Catalogue of Works on Oriental History, Languages and Literature (London: Bernard Quaritch, 1902), p. 26, no. 208.

revisionDesc.change: Jake Benson Created record based upon Rafiee-Rad, with significant corrections to the provenance and also identification of the calligrapher.
